Award.AwardTitle: Virus trafficking in insect midgut cells
Award.AbstractNarration: Arthropods represent the largest animal biomass on earth, including an enormous number of species that cause serious agricultural losses. Arthropods also vector important diseases of plants and animals. Arthropod populations are regulated by many viral diseases. In most interactions between insects and viruses, the virus enters the insect by the oral route and must move across the cells of the gut in order to access the blood and other tissues. Although critical in the virus-insect interaction, little is known about the mechanisms mediating viral trafficking through insect midgut cells. In this project, the investigators will examine the mechanisms of polarized viral transit through the epithelial cells of the insect midgut. This project aims to identify and characterize insect midgut proteins that mediate this process, and the viral protein signals that direct the process. The project will use an innovative experimental design that leverages the power of a Drosophila genetic system, combined with mutagenesis and analysis of model virus envelope proteins, baculovirus GP64 and VSV G. An understanding of the viral signals and the interacting midgut cell proteins and pathways that regulate or restrict virus trafficking through midgut cells can be used to both enhance infection by beneficial viruses (such as those used for biocontrol of insects), and to inhibit viral transmission in insect vectors of plant and animal diseases. Thus, the project should have impacts across a wide variety of virus-insect interactions and with applications in diverse areas such as agricultural crop protection, forestry, and animal and human health. The project includes active participation of a postdoctoral trainee and undergraduate students, and will also engage the public through open-house presentations to local elementary school children, and through presentations to high school teachers and their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many important viruses infect or are transmitted by insects, yet the interactions of these viruses with their insect vectors or hosts are only poorly understood. Critically, very little is known regarding the first interactions of viruses with the cells of the insect midgut. Our studies focused on understanding how viruses move through the cells of the insect midgut. We focused on the questions of how viruses enter cells and how the envelope proteins of viruses are transported through the cells lining the insect midgut. In these studies, we developed three new experimental approaches, which comprise a toolset that will be useful for studies of many specific virus-host interactions with insects. Our studies utilized the well-characterized model insect Drosophila. In parallel, we developed: a) a transgenic system for studies of viral envelope protein transport in the polarized cells of the insect midgut, b) a high throughput RNAi screen for identifying specific proteins and pathways required for virus entry, and c) stable cell lines for studies of viral envelope protein trafficking during virus egress (exit) from the cell. For studies of virus entry, we selected approximately 100 Drosophila proteins predicted to be involved in vesicle transport, and used an RNAi screen to identify a variety of proteins that were either important for entry, or that appear to inhibit entry. The genes/proteins identified from these studies will serve as targets for studies going forward and we are continuing to examine the specific role of one protein that has a dramatic effect on virus entry into the insect cell. Such genes/proteins may serve as targets for intervention strategies in the future; strategies aimed at inhibiting the insect vector’s ability to transmit viruses that cause important diseases of humans or other animals.
